Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every residential tenancy carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment that obligates a landlord to refrain from conduct that substantially and unreasonably interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (N.J..proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every residential tenancy carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment that obligates a landlord to refrain from conduct that substantially and unreasonably interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (N.J..support_reasoning: The case is a Vermont Supreme Court decision, not a Massachusetts case, and it concerns the implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, not an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. While it briefly cites Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway (a Massachusetts case) for the contractual view of residential leases and mutual covenants, Hilder itself does not articulate or apply a Massachusetts common-law rule about a covenant of quiet enjoyment or landlord conduct that substantially interferes with use and enjoyment. Thus, it does not provide direct authority for the specific Massachusetts quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (N.J..relevant_excerpt: Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation. This warranty of habitability is implied in tenancies for a specific period or at will. Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199, 293 N.E.2d 831, 843 (1973).

Javins, 428 F.2d at 1086-87.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when a landlord’s actions or omissions (including failure to repair significant defects) render the premises substantially unsuitable for their intended use or substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment.
Javins, 428 F.2d at 1086-87.case_name: Environmental Defense Fund, Inc. v. United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare, Robert H. Finch, Secretary
Javins, 428 F.2d at 1086-87.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns federal administrative regulation of DDT under the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and the respective responsibilities of HEW and Agriculture. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, leases, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it address when a landlord’s actions or omissions render premises unsuitable for use. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for the stated proposition about breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Javins, 428 F.2d at 1086-87.relevant_excerpt: In this court, petitioners urge that the Secretary’s order refusing to publish their proposal should be reversed on two grounds. First, they argue that their petition, properly interpreted, met all the statutory requirements, including that of “practicability.” Second, they urge that the 1958 amendment to the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, which requires the Secretary to ban any food additive which is found to induce cancer in experimental animals (the Delaney amendment), must be read to require the Secretary not merely to publish their proposal but to establish the “zero tolerance” forthwith.

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is violated when a landlord’s actions or omissions (including failure to repair significant defects) render the premises substantially unsuitable for their intended use or substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The court expressly ties the landlord’s obligations to the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction doctrine, describing that a landlord’s acts or omissions that render premises unfit for their purposes or deprive the tenant of basic services violate the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment. It then formalizes this into an implied warranty of habitability, breached where “bare living requirements” are not met and substantial defects materially affect health and safety—i.e., where the premises are substantially unsuitable for their intended residential use or substantially interfere with use and enjoyment. This squarely matches the proposition’s formulation.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: In the century since the statutes were first enacted, for example, California courts have evolved the “constructive eviction” doctrine as a common law remedy completely independent of this statutory framework; under the modern constructive eviction decisions, a tenant’s right to terminate his lease has not been measured by the standards of sections 1941 or 1942, but by the developing standard that permits abandonment whenever a landlord’s “acts or omissions [render the premises] unfit for the purposes for which they were leased.” (Groh v. Kover’s Bull Pen, Inc. (1963) 221 Cal.App.2d 611, 614 [34 Cal.Rptr. 637] ...). … Under the implied warranty which we recognize, a residential landlord covenants that premises he leases for living quarters will be maintained in a habitable state for the duration of the lease. … it does mean that “bare living requirements” must be maintained. In most cases substantial compliance with those applicable building and housing code standards which materially affect health and safety will suffice to meet the landlord’s obligations.

Kline v. 1500 Massachusetts Ave. Apartme.raw_text: Kline v. 1500 Massachusetts Ave. Apartment Corp., 439 F.2d 477 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Kline v. 1500 Massachusetts Ave. Apartme.proposition: This Complaint relies on and is informed by the following authorities regarding the covenant of quiet enjoyment, landlord obligations, habitability standards, and tenant remedies:
Kline v. 1500 Massachusetts Ave. Apartme.case_name: Sarah B. Kline v. 1500 Massachusetts Avenue Apartment Corporation
Kline v. 1500 Massachusetts Ave. Apartme.support_reasoning: The case directly reconceptualizes the urban residential lease as a contract including a package of services such as safety-related features, recognizes an implied obligation based on habitability and landlord control of common areas, and grounds landlord liability in both contract (implied warranty/expectation of maintained conditions) and tort. It explicitly links these duties to tenant protection and cites Javins and Kendall in terms of habitability, landlord obligations, and tenant remedies. While the focus is security from crime, the reasoning squarely concerns landlord obligations, implied covenants, and tenant protections that inform quiet enjoyment and habitability theories.
Kline v. 1500 Massachusetts Ave. Apartme.relevant_excerpt: “This court noted that the value of the lease to the modern apartment dweller is that it gives him ‘a well known package of goods and services — a package which includes not merely walls and ceilings, but also adequate heat, light and ventilation, serviceable plumbing facilities, secure windows and doors, proper sanitation, and proper maintenance.’… Treating the modern day urban lease as a contract, this court in Javins… delineated the landlord's duty to repair as including continued maintenance… based upon an implied warranty of habitability.… [T]here is implied in the contract between landlord and tenant an obligation on the landlord to provide those protective measures which are within his reasonable capacity.”}

Robinson v. City of Edmonds, 514 U.S. 71.raw_text: Robinson v. City of Edmonds, 514 U.S. 716 (1995)
Robinson v. City of Edmonds, 514 U.S. 71.proposition: This Complaint relies on and is informed by the following authorities regarding the covenant of quiet enjoyment, landlord obligations, habitability standards, and tenant remedies:
Robinson v. City of Edmonds, 514 U.S. 71.support_reasoning: The opinion provided is Hubbard v. United States, dealing with the scope of 18 U.S.C. § 1001 and whether federal courts are ‘departments or agencies’ for that statute. It concerns criminal liability for false statements in judicial proceedings, statutory interpretation, and stare decisis. It does not address landlord–tenant law, quiet enjoyment, habitability, landlord obligations, or tenant remedies, so it cannot support the proposition for which it is cited.
Robinson v. City of Edmonds, 514 U.S. 71.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that a federal court is neither a ‘department’ nor an ‘agency’ within the meaning of § 1001. The Court of Appeals’ decision is therefore reversed to the extent that it upheld petitioner’s convictions under § 1001.” (514 U.S. at 715-16).
